SpinDec2
Software Modelling Spinodal Decomposition

Example - Running Serial With Constant Mobility

To run the code with a constant mobility field, the problem variable in your input.txt file needs to be set to "Constant". Along with this, you must make sure you set the variables \(Mobility\_A\) and \(Mobility\_B\) to the values you want to simulate. In our example we shall set them to \(Mobility\_A\) = 4 and \(Mobility\_B\) = 4. The forward Euler solver is very sensitive to the value of the input parameters, so some suggested values are given in the example input file picture below:


  Concentration_max = 0.6
  Concentration_min = 0.4
  Domain_x_size = 128
  Domain_y_size = 128
  Mobility_A = 4
  Mobility_B = 4
  free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.0001
  Bulk_free_energy = 1
  Checkpointing_interval = 5000
  Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
  Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
  Max_time = 4e-2
  time_step = 1e-6
  Random_seed = 1234
  Use_input = 0
  Exitation_A = 1
  Exitation_B = 1
  Temperature_min = 950
  Temperature_max = 1050
  Problem = "Constant"
  Stabilization_Term = 0

The input file shows all the inputs that the user must specify, however only the mobility parameters will affect how \(M\) is calculated for this case.

The results from the above input file are shown below, and you should expect similar results if you try it yourself:

Changing \(A\) and \(kappa\)

In SpinDec2, you are able to change the bulk free energy scale factor \(A\) for the case where \(f(c) Ac^2(1-c)^2\). Interestingly, you should find that if you increase the scale factor and the free energy gradient parameter by a factor of 10, you should get the same result as the one above, but at a time a tenth of that above. An example input file is shown below:


  Concentration_max = 0.6
  Concentration_min = 0.4
  Domain_x_size = 128
  Domain_y_size = 128
  Mobility_A = 4
  Mobility_B = 4
  free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.001
  Bulk_free_energy = 10
  Checkpointing_interval = 5000
  Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
  Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
  Max_time = 4e-3
  time_step = 1e-7
  Random_seed = 1234
  Use_input = 0
  Exitation_A = 1
  Exitation_B = 1
  Temperature_min = 950
  Temperature_max = 1050
  Problem = "Constant"
  Stabilization_Term = 0

The results from the above input file are shown below, and you should expect similar results if you try it yourself:

Changing only \(\kappa\)

If you however decide that you want to increase \(A\) by ten but don't increase (\kappa\) by the same factor, you find that the mixing of the two alloys becomes less smooth as the interfacial tension reduces in strength.An example input file is shown below:


  Concentration_max = 0.6
  Concentration_min = 0.4
  Domain_x_size = 128
  Domain_y_size = 128
  Mobility_A = 4
  Mobility_B = 4
  free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.001
  Bulk_free_energy = 10
  Checkpointing_interval = 5000
  Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
  Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
  Max_time = 4e-3
  time_step = 1e-7
  Random_seed = 1234
  Use_input = 0
  Exitation_A = 1
  Exitation_B = 1
  Temperature_min = 950
  Temperature_max = 1050
  Problem = "Constant"
  Stabilization_Term = 0

The results from the above input file are shown below, and you should expect similar results if you try it yourself:

Changing The Initial Concentration Range

The starting initial concentration grid will effect the end state of the system. In the previous examples, we have used an initial range of 0.4 to 0.6, which equates to a 50/50 mixture of the two species, as the initial average concentration \(c_0\), is 0.5. If we were to change this to be more biased towards species \(A\) (\(c_0 \approx 0.6\)) or species \(B\), (\(c_0 \approx 0.4\)), then we would expect to have less of a 50/50 split at the end of the simulation, and have clumps of the less dominate element in a sea of the more dominant element. Example input files and expected reults for these cases are shown below:


Concentration_max = 0.65
Concentration_min = 0.64
Domain_x_size = 128
Domain_y_size = 128
Mobility_A = 4
Mobility_B = 4
free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.0001
Bulk_free_energy = 1
Checkpointing_interval = 5000
Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
Max_time = 4e-2
time_step = 1e-6
Random_seed = 1234
Use_input = 0
Exitation_A = 1
Exitation_B = 1
Temperature_min = 950
Temperature_max = 1050
Problem = "Constant"
Stabilization_Term = 0



Concentration_max = 0.32
Concentration_min = 0.31
Domain_x_size = 128
Domain_y_size = 128
Mobility_A = 4
Mobility_B = 4
free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.0001
Bulk_free_energy = 1
Checkpointing_interval = 5000
Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
Max_time = 4e-2
time_step = 1e-6
Random_seed = 1234
Use_input = 0
Exitation_A = 1
Exitation_B = 1
Temperature_min = 950
Temperature_max = 1050
Problem = "Constant"
Stabilization_Term = 0

Changing \(A\) and \(kappa\)

In SpinDec2, you are able to define the bulk free energy polynomial yourself. This is done using the f(c) variable in the input file. The bulk free energy polynomial is crucial in defining how your binary alloy system is going to behave. In particular, the location of the minima will effect the range of values that \(c\) can take. In the previous example, we have used a polynomial where the minimas lie at \(c=0\) and \(c=1\), which is why the range in \(c\) the prevous results have been between 0 and 1 in the final output. If we change the polynomial to be \(f(c) = c^4 - 2c^2 +1\), the minimas are now located at -1 and 1, with the local maxima (i.e the mixed state), now located at \(c = 0\) rather than 0.5. An example input file and expected reults for this case is given below:


  Concentration_max = 0.32
  Concentration_min = 0.31
  Domain_x_size = 128
  Domain_y_size = 128
  Mobility_A = 4
  Mobility_B = 4
  free_energy_gradient_parameter = 0.0001
  Bulk_free_energy = 1
  Checkpointing_interval = 5000
  Checkpoint_output_file = "Out.cp"
  Checkpoint_input_file = "Out.cp"
  Max_time = 4e-2
  time_step = 1e-6
  Random_seed = 1234
  Use_input = 0
  Exitation_A = 1
  Exitation_B = 1
  Temperature_min = 950
  Temperature_max = 1050
  Problem = "Constant"
  Stabilization_Term = 0

Authors: Anas Siddiqui, Ben Gosling, Dyaln Morgan, Geraldine Anis, Matyas Parrag
